title: Getting Started with Easy camara
subtitle: Learn the basic controls and layout in 5 minutes.
body:
# Welcome to Easy camara! üåü

In this first guide, you'll learn the basic layout of the app so you can start shooting better photos and videos in just a few minutes.

---

## üè† Home Screen Overview

When you open Easy camara, you first see the **Home screen**:

‚Ä¢ **Guide Library** - A list of short guides (like this one)  
‚Ä¢ **Pro Camera Button** - Bottom button to start shooting  

> üí° You can read a guide any time, then tap **Open Pro Camera** to start shooting with the settings you just learned.

---

## üì∑ Camera Layout Explained

When you open the camera, you'll discover:

‚Ä¢ **Live Preview** - Central view of your scene  
‚Ä¢ **Shutter Button** - Big button for capturing  
‚Ä¢ **Control Panel** - Settings for resolution, frame rate, LUTs  

---

## üéØ Quick Start Guide

1. **Point** the camera at your subject  
2. **Tap** screen to set focus & exposure  
3. **Press** shutter for photos  
4. **Tap** record for video  

---

## üåü Pro Habits

‚Ä¢ Clean lens before shooting  
‚Ä¢ Keep hands steady  
‚Ä¢ Shoot multiple angles  
‚Ä¢ Use natural light  

---

**Next Steps**: "Best Settings for Daylight Photos" ‚Üí

title: Mastering Pro Controls
subtitle: Understand white balance, exposure, focus, and video options.
body:
# Mastering Pro Controls üéõÔ∏è

Your Pro Controls turn Easy camara into a powerful manual camera. This guide explains each main section in simple language so you know what you are changing and why.

---

## üé® White Balance (WB)

White Balance keeps colors looking natural.

- **Auto** ‚Äì Good for most situations; the app chooses for you.  
- **Manual** ‚Äì Use when you want a consistent look.

Presets you can tap:

- **Day** ‚Äì Outdoor sun  
- **Cloudy** ‚Äì Adds a bit of warmth  
- **Tungsten** ‚Äì Fixes yellow indoor light  
- **Fluoro** ‚Äì Fixes green fluorescent light  

> üí° If skin looks too blue, move temperature to the right. Too orange or yellow? Move it to the left.

---

## üîÜ Exposure Modes

Exposure controls how bright or dark your image is.

- **Auto** ‚Äì Camera picks shutter and ISO automatically.  
- **M (Manual)** ‚Äì You choose both shutter speed and ISO.  
- **S (Shutter Priority)** ‚Äì You fix the shutter; ISO adjusts.  
- **ISO Mode** ‚Äì You fix ISO; shutter adjusts.

Use **EV Compensation** to nudge the brightness up or down without changing your base settings.

> ‚≠ê Start with Auto + EV at 0.0. If the picture is too dark, slide EV to the right; too bright, slide left.

---

## üéØ Focus: AF vs MF

- **AF (Auto Focus)** ‚Äì Tap on your subject and the app focuses there. Great for everyday use.  
- **MF (Manual Focus)** ‚Äì Use the slider to control focus for creative shots.

Manual focus is perfect for:

- Close-up details  
- Shooting through objects (like fences or leaves)  
- Smooth focus pulls in video

---

## üóÇÔ∏è Format & Quality

- **JPEG / HEIF** ‚Äì Ready-to-share photos. HEIF keeps quality high with smaller file size.  
- **RAW / ProRAW** ‚Äì Maximum editing flexibility (best for advanced users).

> üí° If you are not sure, choose **HEIF**.

---

## üé¨ Video Settings Overview

Key sections in the Video panel:

- **Resolution** ‚Äì 720p, 1080p, or 4K  
- **Frame Rate** ‚Äì 24, 30, or 60 fps  
- **Codec** ‚Äì H.264 (compatibility) or HEVC (quality + smaller size)  
- **Color Profile** ‚Äì SDR (normal), HDR, or Log  
- **Bitrate** ‚Äì Std, High, Max

Simple starting point:

- Resolution: **1080p**  
- Frame rate: **30 fps**  
- Codec: **HEVC**  
- Color: **SDR**  
- Bitrate: **High**

---

## üé® Looks / LUTs

Looks are instant color styles.

- **None** ‚Äì Clean and neutral  
- **Warm Classic** ‚Äì Cozy, warm tones  
- **Soft Pastel** ‚Äì Gentle, low-contrast look  
- **Cinematic Teal** ‚Äì Movie-style teal and orange

Use the **Strength** slider to control how strong the look is.

> üí° For natural results, keep strength around 30‚Äì60%.

---

## üìä Monitoring Tools

You can choose what to display while shooting:

- **Histogram** ‚Äì Shows brightness distribution  
- **Waveform** ‚Äì More detailed brightness and color  
- **Audio** ‚Äì Live sound levels

Try leaving **Histogram** on while you learn. A big spike on the far right means highlights may be clipping.

---

## ‚úÖ Simple Pro Setup

1. Set **Resolution** to 1080p and **Frame Rate** to 30 fps.  
2. Use **Auto** exposure at first.  
3. Turn on **Histogram**.  
4. Choose **Warm Classic** LUT at 40‚Äì50% strength.  
5. Use **AF**, but switch to **MF** for close-ups.

---

**Next Steps**: "Best Settings for Daylight Photos" ‚Üí

title: Best Settings for Daylight Photos
subtitle: Simple presets for bright, natural-looking images.
body:
# Best Settings for Daylight Photos ‚òÄÔ∏è

Daylight is the easiest light to work with. With the right settings in Easy camara, you can get sharp, clean photos every time.

---

## ‚úÖ Recommended Base Settings

For most sunny or cloudy daytime scenes:

- **White Balance**: Day or Cloudy (then tweak if needed)  
- **Exposure Mode**: Auto  
- **EV Compensation**: 0.0  
- **Focus**: AF  
- **Format**: HEIF

> üí° If the sky looks too bright, slide EV slightly negative (‚Äì0.3 to ‚Äì0.7).

---

## üë§ Shooting People in Daylight

- Face your subject **toward the light**, but not into harsh sun.  
- Use **Cloudy WB** for a warmer skin tone.  
- Tap on the face to set focus and exposure.  
- If the background is too bright, lower EV a little.

Pose tips:

- Ask them to turn slightly sideways.  
- Take 3‚Äì4 shots in a row to catch natural expressions.

---

## üåÑ Landscapes & Cityscapes

- Use **Day WB** for neutral colors.  
- Lower EV to **‚Äì0.3 or ‚Äì0.7** for deeper skies.  
- Hold the phone steady, and gently tap the shutter.

Composition ideas:

- Use the **Grid** option and place the horizon on the top or bottom third.  
- Include foreground elements (trees, railings, rocks) for depth.

---

## üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Action in Daylight

If your subject is moving (kids running, street scenes):

- Switch **Exposure Mode** to **S (Shutter Priority)**.  
- Use a faster shutter (like 1/500s or faster).  
- Leave ISO on Auto.

This keeps motion sharp while the camera handles brightness.

---

## ‚òÅÔ∏è Overcast or Cloudy Days

- Choose **Cloudy WB** to add warmth.  
- Keep **Auto Exposure** with EV at 0.0.  
- Ask subjects to stand away from dark backgrounds so they stand out.

---

## üîß Quick Fix Checklist

If your daylight photo looks:

- **Too bright** ‚Üí Lower EV or move to shade.  
- **Too dark** ‚Üí Raise EV slightly.  
- **Too blue** ‚Üí Increase WB temperature.  
- **Too yellow** ‚Üí Decrease WB temperature.

---

**Next Steps**: "How to Shoot Cinematic Video" ‚Üí

title: How to Shoot Cinematic Video
subtitle: Turn simple clips into movie-like shots.
body:
# How to Shoot Cinematic Video üé¨

Cinematic video is less about expensive gear and more about smooth motion, good light, and intentional choices. Easy camara gives you all the tools you need.

---

## ‚öôÔ∏è Basic Cinematic Settings

Start with these settings:

- **Resolution**: 1080p or 4K  
- **Frame Rate**: 24 fps for a movie feel  
- **Codec**: HEVC  
- **Color Profile**: SDR (or Log if you color grade)  
- **Bitrate**: High

Turn **Stabilization (Stab)** on for handheld shots.

---

## üîÜ Exposure & White Balance

- Use **S (Shutter Priority)** and set shutter to about **1/48 or 1/50** (double the frame rate).  
- Let ISO adjust automatically.  
- Set **White Balance** manually (Day / Cloudy / Tungsten) so the color does not drift.

> üí° Lock WB before recording to keep the color consistent between shots.

---

## üéØ Focus for Drama

- For simple videos, keep **AF** on and tap your subject.  
- For cinematic focus pulls, switch to **MF** and slowly move the slider from foreground to background.

Ideas:

- Focus from a nearby object to a person in the distance.  
- Start out-of-focus and slowly bring the subject into focus.

---

## üé® Add a Subtle Look

Use a LUT at low strength:

- **Warm Classic** at 30‚Äì40% for soft storytelling.  
- **Cinematic Teal** at 30‚Äì50% for a modern film look.

Avoid using 100% strength unless you want a very stylized image.

---

## üé• Movement Techniques

- Move **slowly and smoothly**; think of floating, not walking.  
- Use two hands and keep elbows close to your body.  
- Try simple moves: push-in, pull-back, or sideways slides.

> üí° Breathe out gently while recording to reduce shake.

---

## üìö Shoot in Sequences

Instead of one long clip, shoot:

1. **Wide shot** ‚Äì Shows the whole scene.  
2. **Medium shot** ‚Äì Shows the subject clearly.  
3. **Close-up** ‚Äì Details (hands, eyes, objects).  

Editing these together instantly feels more cinematic.

---

**Next Steps**: "Understanding ISO, Shutter Speed & Exposure" ‚Üí

title: Understanding ISO, Shutter Speed & Exposure
subtitle: The three pillars of a well-exposed image.
body:
# Understanding ISO, Shutter Speed & Exposure üìö

Exposure is how bright or dark your photo or video looks. In Easy camara, three main settings control it: **ISO**, **Shutter Speed**, and **EV Compensation**.

---

## üî¢ ISO

ISO is the sensor's sensitivity to light.

- **Low ISO (30‚Äì100)** ‚Äì Clean image, less noise, but needs more light.  
- **High ISO (800‚Äì3000+)** ‚Äì Works in darker scenes but adds grain/noise.

> üí° Use the lowest ISO you can while still getting a bright enough image.

---

## ‚è±Ô∏è Shutter Speed

Shutter speed controls **how long** the sensor collects light.

- **Fast shutter** (1/500s, 1/1000s) ‚Äì Freezes motion, less light.  
- **Slow shutter** (1/30s, 1/15s) ‚Äì More motion blur, more light.

For video, a common rule:

- Shutter ‚âà **1 / (2 √ó frame rate)**  
  - 24 fps ‚Üí ~1/48 or 1/50  
  - 30 fps ‚Üí ~1/60  
  - 60 fps ‚Üí ~1/120

This gives natural-looking motion.

---

## üéöÔ∏è EV Compensation

EV Compensation adjusts brightness **after** the camera suggests an exposure.

- **Positive EV (+)** ‚Äì Brighter image.  
- **Negative EV (‚Äì)** ‚Äì Darker image.

Use this instead of constantly changing ISO or shutter if you are in Auto modes.

---

## üß† How They Work Together

Think of it like this:

- ISO = How sensitive your "eyes" are.  
- Shutter = How long your "eyes stay open".  
- EV = Fine-tuning the final brightness.

To fix a dark photo:

1. Lower shutter speed (if subject is not moving fast).  
2. Raise ISO slightly.  
3. Add a bit of positive EV.

To fix a photo that is too bright:

1. Increase shutter speed.  
2. Reduce ISO.  
3. Add a bit of negative EV.

---

## üõ† Simple Practice Exercise

1. Point the camera at a window or bright scene.  
2. Switch to **Manual (M)** mode.  
3. Set ISO low and adjust shutter until the image looks good.  
4. Then raise ISO and see how the histogram and noise change.

Notice how each control changes the look.

---

**Next Steps**: "Manual Focus: When & How to Use It" ‚Üí

title: Manual Focus: When & How to Use It
subtitle: Take control of what is sharp in your frame.
body:
# Manual Focus: When & How to Use It üéØ

Auto Focus is fast and smart, but sometimes you want full control. Manual Focus (MF) lets you decide exactly **what** should be sharp.

---

## üîÅ Switching to Manual Focus

1. Open **Pro Controls**.  
2. In the **Focus** section, choose **MF**.  
3. Use the **focus slider** to move focus from near to far.

Watch the preview and stop when your subject looks sharp.

---

## üìå When Manual Focus Is Better

Use MF when:

- The camera keeps focusing on the wrong object.  
- You are shooting **macro** or very close details.  
- You want a cinematic **focus pull** between two subjects.  
- It is very dark and AF struggles.

---

## üé• Doing a Focus Pull

1. Set your subject A (foreground) and subject B (background).  
2. Start with focus on A using the slider.  
3. Begin recording.  
4. Slowly slide focus toward B while keeping your hand steady.

This simple move instantly looks more professional.

---

## üîç Macro & Detail Shots

For close-up shots (flowers, textures, objects):

- Move your phone **as close as it can still focus**.  
- Switch to MF and fine-tune until the tiny details pop.  
- Keep the phone very steady or use a small tripod.

---

## ‚úÖ Manual Focus Checklist

- Always zoom in a bit (digitally) to check if focus is truly sharp, then zoom back.  
- Combine MF with **grid** overlay to align your subject.  
- Practice small slider movements; big jumps look rough.

---

**Next Steps**: "Best Settings for Low Light & Night Photos" ‚Üí

title: Best Settings for Low Light & Night Photos
subtitle: Reduce noise and keep your shots sharp in the dark.
body:
# Best Settings for Low Light & Night Photos üåô

Low light is challenging but also very rewarding. With the right settings and technique, Easy camara can capture clean, dramatic night images.

---

## ‚öôÔ∏è Suggested Night Settings

Start with:

- **Exposure Mode**: M or S  
- **ISO**: Start around 400‚Äì800  
- **Shutter Speed**: 1/30s to 1/60s for handheld  
- **White Balance**: Tungsten or custom for street lights  
- **Focus**: MF if AF hunts

> üí° If your subject is still and you can brace the phone, you can use slower shutter speeds (1/10s or 1/5s) for more light.

---

## üìâ Controlling Noise

Noise appears when ISO is very high.

- Use the **lowest ISO** that still gives a bright enough image.  
- Brighten the scene if possible (move closer to light, turn on a lamp).  
- Avoid extreme digital zoom; crop later instead.

---

## üßç Staying Sharp at Night

- Hold the phone with **two hands** and tuck elbows into your body.  
- Lean against a wall or table for extra stability.  
- Gently tap the shutter; do not jab at the screen.

If possible, use a small tripod or rest the phone on a solid surface.

---

## üåÜ City Lights & Street Scenes

- Use **Tungsten WB** to balance warm street lamps.  
- Slightly lower EV (‚Äì0.3) to keep highlights from clipping.  
- Look for reflections in wet roads, windows, or cars.

---

## üåå Night Sky & Light Trails

For creative effects (light trails, stars):

- Set **shutter slower** (1/2s, 1s, or longer if available).  
- Keep ISO as low as possible.  
- Use **MF** and focus near infinity.  
- Absolutely use a tripod or very stable surface.

Even small vibrations will blur long exposures.

---

## ‚úÖ Quick Night Checklist

- Avoid very bright lights in the frame unless they are your subject.  
- Take several shots; tiny movement can ruin one but not all.  
- Review images at full zoom to check sharpness.

---

**Next Steps**: "Using LUTs for Professional Looks" ‚Üí

title: Using LUTs for Professional Looks
subtitle: Give your footage style without overdoing it.
body:
# Using LUTs for Professional Looks üé®

LUTs (Look-Up Tables) are presets that change the color and contrast of your image. Easy camara includes several looks that you can apply live.

---

## üé≠ What LUTs Do

A LUT can:

- Shift colors (for example, teal shadows and warm skin).  
- Add or reduce contrast.  
- Change overall mood (warm, cool, pastel, etc.).

They do **not** fix bad lighting or focus, but they can make a good image look great.

---

## üåà Built-in Looks

Common looks you might see:

- **None** ‚Äì Neutral, great for editing later.  
- **Warm Classic** ‚Äì Soft, warm tones ideal for people.  
- **Soft Pastel** ‚Äì Low contrast, dreamy feel.  
- **Cinematic Teal** ‚Äì Modern film-style colors.

---

## üéöÔ∏è Strength Slider

Use the **Strength** control to avoid overdoing the look.

- 0‚Äì30% ‚Üí Very subtle, almost invisible.  
- 30‚Äì60% ‚Üí Natural but stylized (recommended).  
- 60‚Äì100% ‚Üí Strong style; use only when you really want that effect.

> üí° If skin looks strange or highlights look harsh, lower strength.

---

## üß™ Simple Workflow

1. Set your exposure and white balance first.  
2. Choose a LUT that matches the scene mood.  
3. Move the strength slider until it feels right.  
4. Record a short test clip and review it.

Remember: you can always switch back to **None** if you plan to color-grade later.

---

## üîÅ Consistency Between Shots

For a project or vlog episode, try to:

- Use **one main LUT** for all clips.  
- Keep **White Balance** fixed so colors match.  
- Avoid changing strength every shot unless it is a deliberate effect.

---

**Next Steps**: "How to Stabilize Your Shots (No Gimbal Needed)" ‚Üí

title: How to Stabilize Your Shots (No Gimbal Needed)
subtitle: Get smooth footage using only your hands and simple tricks.
body:
# How to Stabilize Your Shots (No Gimbal Needed) üßò

Shaky video can ruin great content. Luckily, you can get much smoother footage with simple techniques and Easy camara's tools.

---

## ‚úÖ Turn On Stabilization

In the Video Pro Controls, make sure **Stab** is enabled.

This uses software stabilization to smooth out small hand movements.

---

## üßç Body Position & Grip

- Hold the phone with **both hands**.  
- Tuck elbows gently into your body.  
- Keep your body relaxed, not stiff.

When walking:

- Bend your knees slightly.  
- Take slow, soft steps.  
- Move your upper body like a steady "floating" rig.

---

## üß± Use the World Around You

- Lean against a wall, pole, or table.  
- Rest your phone on railings, benches, or books.  
- Slide the phone along a smooth surface for dolly-like shots.

---

## üé• Short Moves, Not Long Walks

Instead of long walking shots:

- Do **short, controlled moves** (1‚Äì3 seconds).  
- Stop, reframe, then do another move.

These edit together better and look smoother.

---

## üîä Watch Audio Too

If you see very high peaks in the audio meter while moving, you might be bumping the phone or touching the mic area. Adjust your grip to keep fingers away from the microphones.

---

## üßæ Quick Stability Checklist

- Stabilization on  
- Two-hand grip  
- Elbows in  
- Slow feet and breathing  
- Use walls, tables, and objects for support

---

**Next Steps**: "Complete Mobile Filmmaking Tips" ‚Üí

title: Complete Mobile Filmmaking Tips
subtitle: From idea to final shot using Easy camara.
body:
# Complete Mobile Filmmaking Tips üé•üì±

Now that you know the tools inside Easy camara, this guide ties everything together into a simple workflow you can use for vlogs, short films, or travel videos.

---

## üìù 1. Plan Before You Shoot

You do not need a big script, just a clear idea:

- What is this video about?  
- Who or what is the main subject?  
- Where will you shoot it?  
- How long should it be?

Make a quick shot list:

- Wide shot  
- Medium shot  
- Close-up  
- Extra details (hands, environment, objects)

---

## ‚öôÔ∏è 2. Set Up Your Camera Once

Before recording:

- Choose **Resolution**, **Frame Rate**, and **Codec** for the whole project.  
- Pick one **LUT** (or None) and stick with it.  
- Lock **White Balance** for consistency.  
- Turn on **Histogram** to avoid clipping.

This keeps all clips looking like they belong in the same story.

---

## üîÜ 3. Light Is Everything

- Prefer **natural light** near windows or outdoors.  
- Avoid strong mixed lighting (daylight + green fluorescent).  
- At night, move your subject closer to the brightest light source.

Remember: it is easier to make a well-lit shot more dramatic than to rescue a dark, noisy one.

---

## üéô 4. Treat Audio Seriously

- Watch the **audio meters**; aim for around ‚Äì12 dB to ‚Äì6 dB.  
- Record in a quiet place when possible.  
- Get the phone closer to the sound source instead of shouting.

Good audio makes your video feel professional even if the visuals are simple.

---

## üé¨ 5. Shoot in Pieces, Not in One Take

For each moment:

1. Start with a **wide shot** to show context.  
2. Capture a **medium shot** of the subject.  
3. Grab **close-ups** of faces, hands, or important details.  
4. Add a few **cutaway shots** (sky, buildings, background people).

These pieces give you flexibility when editing.

---

## üß† 6. Keep the Story Clear

Even short clips should have:

- A **beginning** (where are we? who is here?)  
- A **middle** (what happens?)  
- An **end** (what changed or what did we learn?)

Think about what you want viewers to **feel** at the end.

---

## ‚úÖ 7. Simple Workflow Summary

1. Plan your story and shot list.  
2. Set Pro Controls once at the start.  
3. Use stable handholding or support surfaces.  
4. Watch exposure, focus, and audio meters.  
5. Shoot multiple angles of each moment.  
6. Keep clips short and intentional.

---

**Next Steps**: Explore other guides in the **Guide Library** or re-read any topic you want to practice again. Easy camara will grow with your skills. üåü
